title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price (Continuous)
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond using continuous compounding. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a coupon bond. P represents the bond price

notes: This equation calculates the price of an annual coupon bond using the annuity formula. P represents the bond price

notes: This equation calculates the price of a semi-annual coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Bond Price Between Coupon Dates
notes: This equation calculates the bond price between coupon dates

title: Accrued Interest
equation_latex: A \times \text{I} = \text{C} * (D \times ay \times s s \times in \times ce l \times as \times t c \times ou \times po \times n / D \times ay \times s i \times n c \times ou \times po \times n p \times er \times io \times d)
notes: This equation calculates the accrued interest on a bond between coupon dates. AI represents the accrued interest This equation is fundamental to the time value of money concept, which states that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity. The mathematical formulation captures how capital compounds over time, forming the foundation for all discounted cash flow analysis.

title: Dirty Price
equation_latex: D \times \text{P} = \text{C} \times le \times an \text{P} \times ri \times ce + A \times cc \times ru \times ed \text{I} \times nt \times er \times es \times t
notes: This equation expresses the relationship between dirty price and clean price. DP represents the dirty price (full price)

title: Yield to Maturity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the yield to maturity for a zero-coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity as a decimal

title: Yield to Maturity (Coupon Bond)
notes: This equation defines the yield to maturity for a coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity that equates the present value of all cash flows to the current price P. The YTM for coupon bonds must be solved numerically (e.g.

title: Current Yield
notes: This equation calculates the current yield of a bond. CY represents the current yield

title: Yield to Call (First Call)
equation_latex: \text{P} = s \times um_{t=1}^{n_{c}} \text{C}/(1 + y_{t \times c})^{t} + F_{c}/(1 + y_{t \times c})^{n_{c}}
notes: This equation calculates the yield to call for a callable bond. y_{tc} represents the yield to call

title: Yield to Worst
notes: YTC_2

title: Zero-Coupon Yield Curve
notes: This equation extracts the zero-coupon yield curve from zero-coupon bond prices. r_t represents the continuously compounded zero rate for maturity t

title: Par Yield
notes: This equation calculates the par yield from zero-coupon discount factors. y_par represents the par yield (coupon rate that prices the bond at par)

title: Forward Rate from Spot Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Forward Rate (Continuous)
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Instantaneous Forward Rate
equation_latex: f \times (t) = r \times (t) + t * d \times r \times (t)/d \times t
notes: This equation defines the instantaneous forward rate. f(t) represents the instantaneous forward rate for time t

title: Spot Rate from Forward Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Nelson-Siegel Yield Curve
equation_latex: y \times (t) = b \times et \times a_{0} + b \times et \times a_{1} * (1 - e^{-t/t \times au})/(t/t \times au) + b \times et \times a_{2} * ((1 - e^{-t/t \times au})/(t/t \times au) - e^{-t/t \times au})
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel parameterization of the yield curve. y(t) represents the yield at time t

title: Nelson-Siegel-Svensson Extension
equation_latex: y \times (t) = b \times et \times a_{0} + b \times et \times a_{1} * (1 - e^{-t/t \times au_{1}})/(t/t \times au_{1}) + b \times et \times a_{2} * ((1 - e^{-t/t \times au_{1}})/(t/t \times au_{1}) - e^{-t/t \times au_{1}}) + b \times et \times a_{3} * ((1 - e^{-t/t \times au_{2}})/(t/t \times au_{2}) - e^{-t/t \times au_{2}})
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel-Svensson extension with an additional hump term. y(t) represents the yield at time t

title: Yield Curve Steepness
equation_latex: \text{S} \times lo \times pe = y_{10 \times y} - y_{2 \times y}
notes: This equation measures the steepness of the yield curve. Slope represents the difference between the 10-year yield and the 2-year yield. A positive slope indicates an upward-sloping yield curve (normal)

title: Yield Curve Curvature
equation_latex: \text{C} \times ur \times va \times tu \times re = 2 * y_{10 \times y} - y_{2 \times y} - y_{30 \times y}
notes: This equation measures the curvature (hump) of the yield curve. Curvature captures the non-linearity of the yield curve shape. A positive curvature indicates a hump-shaped yield curve

title: Butterfly Spread
equation_latex: B \times ut \times te \times rf \times ly = y_{10 \times y} - (y_{2 \times y} + y_{30 \times y})/2
notes: This equation calculates the butterfly spread of the yield curve. Butterfly measures the deviation of the intermediate yield from the average of the short and long yields. It's a key measure for yield curve strategies and relative value analysis.

title: Macaulay Duration
equation_latex: D_{m}a \times c = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} (t * \text{C} \times F_{t} / (1 + y)^{t}) / \text{P}
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a bond. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Macaulay Duration (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation shows that the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond equals its time to maturity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Macaulay Duration (Perpetuity)
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a perpetuity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Modified Duration
notes: This equation calculates the modified duration from Macaulay duration. D_mod represents the modified duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Modified Duration (Approximation)
notes: This equation approximates modified duration using finite differences. D_mod represents the modified duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Dollar Duration
notes: This equation calculates the dollar duration (also called PV01 or DV01). DD represents the dollar duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Price Value of a Basis Point
notes: This equation calculates the price value of a basis point (PV01). PV01 represents the price change for a 1 basis point (0.01%) change in yield. PV01 is a standard risk measure used in fixed income markets and is equivalent to dollar duration scaled by 0.0001.

title: Effective Duration
notes: This equation calculates the effective duration for bonds with embedded options. D_eff represents the effective duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Key Rate Duration
equation_latex: \text{K} \times RD_{i} = -(\text{P} \times (y + d \times y_{i}) - \text{P} \times (y - d \times y_{i})) / (2 * \text{P} * d \times y_{i})
notes: This equation calculates the key rate duration for a specific key rate. KRD_i represents the key rate duration for key rate i Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Convexity
equation_latex: \text{C} \times on \times v = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} (t \times (t+1) * \text{C} \times F_{t} / (1 + y)^{t+2}) / \text{P}
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond. Conv represents convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships, accounting for the curvature that makes bond prices rise more for yield drops than they fall for equivalent yield increases. This curvature adjustment improves price estimates for large yield changes beyond what duration alone can predict.

title: Convexity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a zero-coupon bond. Conv represents the convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships, accounting for the curvature that makes bond prices rise more for yield drops than they fall for equivalent yield increases. This curvature adjustment improves price estimates for large yield changes beyond what duration alone can predict.

title: Convexity (Perpetuity)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a perpetuity. Conv represents the convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships, accounting for the curvature that makes bond prices rise more for yield drops than they fall for equivalent yield increases. This curvature adjustment improves price estimates for large yield changes beyond what duration alone can predict.

title: Effective Convexity
equation_latex: \text{C} \times on \times v_{e}f \times f = (P_+ + P_- - 2 \times \text{P}) / (\text{P} * d \times y^{2})
notes: This equation calculates the effective convexity for bonds with embedded options. Conv_eff represents the effective convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships, accounting for the curvature that makes bond prices rise more for yield drops than they fall for equivalent yield increases. This curvature adjustment improves price estimates for large yield changes beyond what duration alone can predict.

title: Dollar Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the dollar convexity. DC represents the dollar convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships, accounting for the curvature that makes bond prices rise more for yield drops than they fall for equivalent yield increases. This curvature adjustment improves price estimates for large yield changes beyond what duration alone can predict.

title: Price Change Approximation
equation_latex: d \times \text{P}/\text{P} ≈ -D_{m}o \times d * d \times y + 0.5 * \text{C} \times on \times v * (d \times y)^{2}
notes: This equation approximates the percentage price change of a bond for a small change in yield. dP/P represents the percentage price change

title: Taylor Series Expansion
notes: This is the Taylor series expansion of bond price with respect to yield. P(y + dy) is the new price

title: Bond Portfolio Duration
equation_latex: D_{p}o \times rt = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * D_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the duration of a bond portfolio. D_port represents the portfolio duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Bond Portfolio Convexity
equation_latex: \text{C} \times on \times v_{p}o \times rt = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * \text{C} \times on \times v_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond portfolio. Conv_port represents the portfolio convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships, accounting for the curvature that makes bond prices rise more for yield drops than they fall for equivalent yield increases. This curvature adjustment improves price estimates for large yield changes beyond what duration alone can predict.

title: Immunization Condition 1
notes: This is the first immunization condition for matching asset and liability durations. D_A represents the duration of assets

title: Immunization Condition 2
notes: This is the second immunization condition. Conv_A represents the convexity of assets

title: Reinvestment Risk
equation_latex: R_{r}e \times in \times v = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} \text{C} \times F_{t} * ((1 + y_{r})^{n-t} - (1 + y)^{n-t})
notes: This equation calculates the reinvestment risk of a bond. R_reinv represents the reinvestment risk

title: Price Risk
notes: This equation calculates the price risk of a bond. R_price represents the price risk

title: Total Bond Risk
equation_latex: R_{t}o \times ta \times l = R_{p}r \times ic \times e + R_{r}e \times in \times v
notes: This equation calculates the total bond risk. R_total represents the total risk

title: Spread Duration
equation_latex: D_{s}p \times re \times ad = -(\text{P} \times (y + d \times y + d \times s) - \text{P} \times (y + d \times y - d \times s)) / (2 * \text{P} * d \times s)
notes: This equation calculates the spread duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income markets, representing the weighted average time to cash flows. Modified duration directly estimates percentage price changes for yield movements using the first derivative of the price-yield relationship. Higher duration means greater sensitivity to rate changes.

title: Yield Beta
equation_latex: b \times et \times a = (d \times P_{b}o \times nd / P_{b}o \times nd) / (d \times P_{b}e \times nc \times hm \times ar \times k / P_{b}e \times nc \times hm \times ar \times k)
notes: This equation calculates the yield beta of a bond relative to a benchmark. beta represents the yield beta The cost of capital represents the required return that investors demand for providing capital. It serves as the discount rate for valuation and the hurdle rate for investment decisions, reflecting both the time value of money and compensation for risk.

title: Tracking Error
equation_latex: \text{T} \times \text{E} = s \times qr \times t \times ((1/\text{T}) * s \times um_{t=1}^{\text{T}} (R_{p}o \times rt \times fo \times li \times o

title: Information Ratio
equation_latex: \text{I} \times R = (R_{p}o \times rt \times fo \times li \times o - R_{b}e \times nc \times hm \times ar \times k) / \text{T} \times \text{E}
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio of a bond portfolio. IR represents the information ratio
